243.meaning_mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>man</radical>.

742.meaning_mnemonic: You don't want to keep all the <radical>alcohol</radical> to yourself (<radical>oneself</radical>), so you <kanji>distribute</kanji> it to all of your friends. Heck, not just your friends, to everyone you can find!
742.meaning_hint: Don't be that person who keeps the alcohol all to themselves. Distribute it to all of the legally-aged people you know!
742.reading_mnemonic:
As you <kanji>distribute</kanji> the alcohol you say a <reading>hai</reading>ku (<ja>はい</ja>):

Here you go my friends
Alcohol for everyone
Never drink alone
742.reading_hint: This becomes the haiku you say before every party, every potluck, and every night out at the bar. You even get it tattoo'd to your arm.

931.meaning_mnemonic: When you see the <radical>spring</radical> <radical>sun</radical> you know it's finally the  <kanji>spring</kanji> season.
931.meaning_hint: The spring sun only comes out in spring, which is why you know for sure it's spring. Imagine a different looking sun that only comes out in spring but not the other seasons.
931.reading_mnemonic: When the <kanji>spring</kanji> season comes around, it makes you want to laugh: "<reading>HAR</reading> (<ja>はる</ja>) HAR HAR!" you yell.
931.reading_hint: Go ahead and belt out a few "HAR HAR HARs" for spring. It's warming up, everything is coming to life, and you're happy. "HAR HAR HAR!"

942.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>simple</radical> radical and the <kanji>simple</kanji> kanji are the same!
942.reading_mnemonic: One of the most <kanji>simple</kanji> things in the world is getting a <reading>tan</reading> (<ja>たん</ja>). All you have to do is stand outside long enough. It doesn't matter what skin type you have or what the weather is like. Eventually, if you stand out there long enough, you'll get a tan.
942.reading_hint: Get a tan, it's simple, stupid! (Though it's terrible for you so uh... don't always take our advice, kay?)

3067.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>number</kanji> <kanji>letter</kanji> isn't a letter like the ones you're reading now, it's more like a <vocabulary>numeral</vocabulary>, like 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, etc.
3067.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: Regardless of the increase in numbers, you shouldn’t publish vulgar news stories.
context_sentences.ja: 数字がのびるからといって、下ひんなきじをけいさいするのはよした方がいい。

context_sentences.en: This child is a genius who memorized a 15,672-digit number.
context_sentences.ja: この子は、一万五千六百七十二けたの数字をあん記している天才じです。

context_sentences.en: Eleven is the number I always wear when I play volleyball.
context_sentences.ja: 数字の十一は、私がバレーボールをする時にいつも身に付ける背番号です。

3233.meaning_mnemonic: This is the adverb version of the kanji, so it has the same meaning, basically. You can say this is <vocabulary>the most</vocabulary> or just <vocabulary>most</vocabulary>. You can also use it as <vocabulary>extremely</vocabulary>.
3233.reading_mnemonic:
The reading for this is a reading you didn't learn with the kanji (the kun'yomi reading). To learn it, let's look at a mnemonic. 

Think of <vocabulary>the most</vocabulary> ridiculous <reading>motto</reading> (<ja>もっと</ja>) you've ever heard. Now imagine a motto that's even more ridiculous. Here are some actual totally real mottos that are the most ridiculous: "What Can Brown Do for You?" "It's Not for Women" "If It Doesn't Get All Over the Place, It Doesn't Belong in Your Face" and of course, "Why Not Enjoy the Go?"

context_sentences.en: The summer solstice is the shortest night of the year.
context_sentences.ja: げしとは、一年で最も夜がみじかくなる日のことだ。

context_sentences.en: Mt. Fuji is the tallest mountain in Japan.
context_sentences.ja: ふじ山は日本で最も高い山です。

context_sentences.en: Do you know what he ate tonight? He went to an all you can eat yakiniku restaurant. We’d better prepare for the smelliest farts imaginable. Better safe than sorry.
context_sentences.ja: 彼、今日の夜何食べたか知ってる？焼き肉食べ放題に行ったんだよ。最も臭いおならに備えておいた方が身のためだよ。用心に越したことはないんだから。

3476.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>付ける</ja> means "to attach" and that <ja>見</ja> means "see." So, when you attach your seeing to something, it's like you're looking around trying <vocabulary>to find</vocabulary> something. When you find what you're looking for, imagine your eyeballs flying out and attaching to that item, then yelling "I FOUND IT!"
3476.reading_mnemonic: The readings come from <ja>見る</ja> and <ja>付ける</ja>. If you use those readings, you'll be able to read this word too.

context_sentences.en: The moment you find a bug bite it makes you itchy, don't you think?
context_sentences.ja: むしさされって、見付けるととたんにかゆくなるよな。

context_sentences.en: This hat might help us find Koichi's wig.
context_sentences.ja: このぼう子は、コウイチのかつらを見付けるための手がかりになるかもしれません。

context_sentences.en: I spent over four hours this morning trying to find the pot of gold that they say is at the end of the rainbow.
context_sentences.ja: 私は今朝、虹の端にあると言われている金の壺を見付けるために四時間以上も費やしました。

3606.meaning_mnemonic: When a <kanji>person</kanji> is <kanji>kill</kanji>ed, you have yourself a <vocabulary>murder</vocabulary>.
3606.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: There is some truth to that mother's motive for murder.
context_sentences.ja: あの母親の殺人の動きは分からなくもない。

context_sentences.en: The company, which until now had specialized in online Japanese learning resources, has for the first time released a hard-core murder game.
context_sentences.ja:
今まで、オンライン日本語学習教ざいを専門としていた会社が、
初めて本かくてきな殺人ゲームを発売しました。

context_sentences.en: From a murderer's perspective, I am not very pleased with her because her methods of killing are so boring.
context_sentences.ja: 一人の殺人者として言わせてもらうけど、俺はあまり彼女を評価していないよ。殺人方法がつまらないからね。

3649.meaning_mnemonic:
This one makes no sense (sorry!). When you <kanji>join</kanji> together with someone at a <kanji>metropolis</kanji>, you do it <vocabulary>at your convenience</vocabulary>. You're important, after all, so you just do what you want and make the other person wait in this giant metropolis while you move along leisurely. Imagine this, and keep thinking "at your convenience" as you walk about.

This word is usually used in a nicer way, though. As in, "do it at your convenience!"
3649.reading_mnemonic:
The reading for <ja>都</ja> is an exception from what you learned with the kanji. To remember this, just think about someone who does something at their own convenience. They say, I'm going <reading>to go</reading> (<ja>つごう</ja>) where I want, when I want, at my own convenience.

The <ja>合</ja> (<ja>ごう)</ja> part is a reading you know from the kanji, though, so if you can get to "to go" with the mnemonic, you should be able to put two and two together to know that it's a long vowel <ja>ごう</ja>.

context_sentences.en: I'll get in touch with you as soon as possible.
context_sentences.ja: 都合がつき次第、こちらかられんらくします。

context_sentences.en: Depending on the circumstances, Koichi's wedding ceremony may be postponed.
context_sentences.ja: 都合次第では、コウイチのけっこんしきはえん期になるかもしれません。

context_sentences.en: "Which day is convenient for you, Saturday or Sunday?" "It makes no difference to me."
context_sentences.ja: 「土曜日と日曜日、どちらの方が都合がいい？」「どちらでもいいよ。」

3787.meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>England</kanji> <kanji>country</kanji> is where England is. This word can refer to <vocabulary>Britain</vocabulary>, the <vocabulary>United Kingdom</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>England</vocabulary>!

Note that <ja>イギリス</ja> is more common for "England" - but, since this is a kanji learning website you should learn this word.
3787.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: It was very tough work persuading the stubborn British prime minister, wasn't it?
context_sentences.ja: あの頑固な英国首相をせっとくするのはとても大変だったでしょう？

context_sentences.en: A great number of people visit United Kingdom to golf every year.
context_sentences.ja: 毎年、大変な数の人たちが、ゴルフをしに英国をおとずれます。

context_sentences.en: The UK has an antagonistic relationship with the US.
context_sentences.ja: 英国と米国は敵対関係にある。

3881.meaning_mnemonic: You've seen that <ja>消す</ja> is "to extinguish." So, this is another verb version of that. This time, you're not doing the extinguishing, it's just happening. Something is going <vocabulary>to disappear</vocabulary> on its own. How can you differentiate this from <ja>消す</ja>? Well, <ja>える</ja> allows you to notice how the object disappeared into thin <reading>air</reading> (<ja>える</ja>). You know you didn't do it, so it disappeared on its own, making it <vocabulary>to disappear</vocabulary>.
3881.reading_mnemonic: The reading is different from <ja>消す</ja>, unfortunately, so you can't use that. Just think about how after the object in front of you disappears you use a <reading>key</reading> (<ja>き</ja>) to open an invisible door. That's where everything's disappearing to! You see all your disappeared stuff on the other side of this invisible door which you opened with a magical <reading>key</reading>.

context_sentences.en: WaniKani makes most of my income disappear.
context_sentences.ja: ワニカニにしゅう入の大半が消えます。

context_sentences.en: My eyebrows have worn off from my sweat.
context_sentences.ja: あせでまゆ毛が消えてしまいました。

context_sentences.en: He waved goodbye until she completely disappeared from view.
context_sentences.ja: 彼は、彼女が視界から完全に消えるまで、さようならと手を振り続けた。

3913.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>business</kanji> of you <kanji>graduating</kanji> is your <vocabulary>graduation</vocabulary>. If you think about it, it's kind of a big business, getting you graduated from expensive schools. The graduation business focuses on graduations, and getting you there (hint: this business is a school, probably).
3913.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: In Japan, March is graduation season.
context_sentences.ja: 日本では三月が卒業のシーズンです。

context_sentences.en: Viet made an idol group called TFG48 and has been performing at its center for a long time, but it still doesn't look like he'll graduate. He is already 58 years old.
context_sentences.ja: ビエトはTFG48というアイドルグループを作ってずっとセンターをつとめているが、いつまでたっても卒業する気配がない。もう58才なのに。

context_sentences.en: Teacher, do you think that being able to speak Japanese increases a graduate’s chances of finding a job?
context_sentences.ja: 先生は、日本語が話せると、卒業生の就職の可能性が高くなると思いますか？

3915.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>完全</ja> means "complete" or "perfect." So, a <kanji>not</kanji> "complete" or "perfect" is something that is <vocabulary>incomplete</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>imperfect</vocabulary>.
3915.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It also will help if you can read <ja>完全</ja>.

context_sentences.en: What kind of love is imperfect?
context_sentences.ja: 不完全な形のあいってどんなものですか。

context_sentences.en: Aren't incomplete things better than complete things, since they have a humanness about them?
context_sentences.ja: 完全なものよりも不完全なものの方が人情味があってよくない？

context_sentences.en: The Tofugu softball team had an incomplete end to their season when the game they were winning was suspended due to rain.
context_sentences.ja: 勝ち試合が雨で中止になり、Tofuguソフトボールチームのシーズンが不完全に終わった。

3916.meaning_mnemonic: You know <ja>美術</ja> is <kanji>fine art</kanji>. So what is a <kanji>public building</kanji> that contains said fine art? It's a <vocabulary>museum</vocabulary>.
3916.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: I liked the picture of Noah's ark that was displayed at the art gallery.
context_sentences.ja: その美術館にかざられていたノアの箱ぶねの絵が好きでした。

context_sentences.en: I donated the ring handed down to me from my mother to the museum.
context_sentences.ja: 母が残してくれた指輪を、美術館にき付しました。

context_sentences.en: "How can you be a tour guide in the museum? Don’t you have to be an art expert or something?" "No, not really. They give you all the information, it’s like memorizing a script."
context_sentences.ja: 「どうやって美術館のツアーガイドになれるの？芸術の専門家か何かじゃなくちゃいけないんじゃないの？」「いいや、そうでもないよ。 美術館が情報を全部くれるから、まぁ、台詞を覚えるようなもんだよ。」

7586.meaning_mnemonic: Remember how <ja>動物</ja> means animal? Well when you add <kanji>park</kanji> it becomes a <vocabulary>zoo</vocabulary>. It's a park for animals. Except the animals can't leave. Ever.
7586.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: Even yakuza can come to the zoo.
context_sentences.ja: ヤクザだって動物園に来ることもあるさ。

context_sentences.en: The flamingos looked so beautiful when I saw them up close at a zoological garden.
context_sentences.ja: 動物園で間近で見たフラミンゴは、とてもきれいでした。

context_sentences.en: Many koala bears have an innate virus called koala retrovirus and it often causes a life-threatening diseases like lymphoma when they get stressed out, so please make sure not to use your camera's flash or speak loudly when you go to the menagerie.
context_sentences.ja: 多くのコアラはコアラレトロウィルスというウイルスを先天的に保持しており、ストレスなどを受けると、リンパ腫など死につながる病気を発症してしまいます。ですので、動物園に行かれた際は、カメラのフラッシュや大声を出すなどしないよう、十分気をつけてください。

8669.meaning_mnemonic: A person whose <kanji>idea</kanji>s are <kanji>ground</kanji>ed in <kanji>evil</kanji> is a <vocabulary>malicious</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>mean</vocabulary> <vocabulary>jerk</vocabulary>!
8669.reading_mnemonic: This reading is a combination of the on'yomi readings for <ja>意</ja> and <ja>地</ja>, and the kun'yomi reading for <ja>悪</ja>. You've learned them all already, so this should be cake!

context_sentences.en: Don't waste your precious time on such a jerk.
context_sentences.ja: 折角の時間をあんな意地悪なやつのためにむだにするなんてもったいないよ。

context_sentences.en: This fairy is cute but malicious.
context_sentences.ja: このようせいは、かわいいけど意地悪です。

context_sentences.en: Why are you so mean to my little sister?!
context_sentences.ja: どうして妹に意地悪ばっかりするの！

8804.meaning_mnemonic: If something is <kanji>special</kanji> you <kanji>choose</kanji> it. That makes it a <vocabulary>special selection</vocabulary> of yours and it gets a <vocabulary>special prize</vocabulary> that only you could give!
8804.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: The picture of our boss won the special prize at the contest!
context_sentences.ja: 親分の絵が、コンクールで特選に入賞したぞ！

context_sentences.en: Here are the specially selected cosplayers.
context_sentences.ja: こちらが、特選されたコスプレイヤーの方々です。

context_sentences.en: I heard that Koichi eats the best, specially selected black garlic before going to bed every night.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチは、毎晩寝る前に特選の極上黒大蒜を食べるそうだ。
